summary: This document is an email chain from November 14, 2019, discussing New York Times reporting on a proposed victims' compensation fund by Jeffrey Epstein's estate, and includes embedded news articles about new lawsuits filed against the estate. It details legal strategies, objections from victims' lawyers, and the ongoing civil litigation following Epstein's death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure whose estate is the subject of proposed compensation funds and multiple lawsuits for sexual abuse. He died by suicide in August 2019 while facing federal charges.

persons.name: Kenneth R. Feinberg
persons.context: Retained by Epstein's estate to set up a claims resolution program for accusers.

persons.name: Camille Biros
persons.context: Tapped to help set up the claims resolution program; an architect of programs for Catholic Church abuse scandal victims.

persons.name: Jordana Feldman
persons.context: Tapped to help set up and carry out the claims resolution program; played a critical role in the September 11 Victims Compensation Fund.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Filed a court document stating his client does not believe alternative dispute resolution should stay the course of litigation.

persons.name: Roberta Kaplan
persons.context: Objected to the estate's compensation plan being developed without consulting accusers and their lawyers, calling it 'a continuation of his crimes and abuse after his death.'

persons.name: David Brodie
persons.context: Said he was 'cautiously optimistic' about a resolution program but had questions about how claims would be handled to avoid exacerbating victimization.

persons.name: Bennet Moskowitz
persons.context: Hired by the estate to handle lawsuits by accusers; did not respond to requests for comment.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.role: Executor of Epstein's estate, Epstein's longtime lawyer
persons.context: Named executor of Epstein's estate and a defendant in lawsuits against the estate. Did not respond to requests for comment.

persons.name: Richard Kahn
persons.role: Executor of Epstein's estate, accountant for Epstein's companies
persons.context: Named executor of Epstein's estate and a defendant in lawsuits against the estate. Did not respond to requests for comment.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Represented at least three accusers in new lawsuits against the estate. Called a settlement program 'a positive step' but 'only the first step.' Previously represented an accuser in a defamation suit against Alan Dershowitz.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Accused of procuring young women and underage girls for Epstein and participating in the abuse. Named in lawsuits described in the embedded articles.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Mentioned in a lawsuit as visiting Epstein's mansion when young girls were present. He forcefully denies all allegations and is engaged in legal feuds with Boies Schiller and accusers.

persons.name: Joshua Schiller
persons.context: Named as a lawyer representing accusers in the Boies Schiller lawsuits.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Named as a lawyer representing accusers in the Boies Schiller lawsuits.

persons.name: Matthew Goldstein
persons.context: Author of the New York Times article about the potential victims' fund.

persons.name: Tom McParland
persons.context: Author of the article about Boies Schiller suing the Epstein estate.

events.title: Epstein's Death in Custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein killed himself in August 2019 while facing federal sex trafficking charges at the Manhattan Correctional Center.

events.title: Federal Indictment Dismissed
events.description: Federal prosecutors dismissed the sex-trafficking indictment against Epstein after his suicide.

events.title: New Lawsuits Filed Against Estate
events.description: Boies Schiller Flexner filed at least three new lawsuits in Manhattan federal court on behalf of women accusing Epstein of sexual abuse.

events.title: Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty in Florida state court to soliciting prostitution from a minor. Court filings estimated he had sexual activity with at least 30 underage girls.

events.title: Prosecutors Meet with Accusers
events.description: Representatives from the U.S. attorney's office in Manhattan met with some of Epstein's accusers and lawyers to discuss the ongoing investigation, stating they were looking at charges against people who may have helped Epstein.

events.title: Victims Fund Proposal Disclosed
events.description: A court filing disclosed that lawyers for Epstein's estate were considering a 'claims resolution program' to pay accusers, to be administered by Kenneth Feinberg.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's estate, valued at about $577 million, proposed a 'claims resolution program' administered by Kenneth Feinberg to pay accusers, but faced immediate resistance from some victims' lawyers.
Three new lawsuits were filed against Epstein's estate in November 2019, with allegations detailing abuse occurring between 1995 and 2002 and implicating Ghislaine Maxwell.
One lawsuit referenced Alan Dershowitz visiting Epstein's mansion when young girls were present, which Dershowitz categorically denied, fueling an ongoing legal feud with attorney David Boies.
Following Epstein's death, federal prosecutors dismissed the criminal case but continued investigating his associates for potential charges related to the conspiracy.

Accusers were utilizing a new New York law allowing child victims of sexual abuse to file claims for damages many years later, with the legal clock starting after Epstein's indictment was dismissed on August 29, 2019.
